reasoning: The critique targets how the essay operationalizes “best feasible future,” which matters because the paper normalizes value (0=extinction, 1=best-feasible) and defines ‘mostly-great’/‘near-best’ thresholds relative to it; shifting feasibility constraints could change how hard ‘mostly-great’ is to reach (moderate centrality). However, the position explicitly defines ‘best feasible’ as a high percentile of a ‘well-informed probability distribution’ over futures (and later conditions on survival and on limited de dicto optimization), which already bakes in practical constraints like coordination/psychology/game theory insofar as they affect likelihood. So the critique’s “moving target/oscillation” charge is only weakly supported by the text, making the refutation limited (low strength). Still, it’s broadly correct that ambiguity about what the reference distribution includes (e.g., what counts as ‘feasible’ vs merely ‘possible’) could affect conclusions if left underspecified, so correctness is moderate-high. The point is clearly stated, focused on one issue, and contains little-to-no dead weight.
title: Shifting definitions of feasibility create an unfairly moving target
